unnormalised: **Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Quality Control Concerns Emerge in Auto Ancillary Sector**
normalised: **manufacturing and supply chain: quality control concerns emerge in auto ancillary sector**

unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26 – Concerns are mounting over quality control procedures in India's auto ancillary sector, particularly among smaller vendors supplying components to major manufacturers like Maruti Suzuki and Tata Motors. Recent audits have revealed inconsistencies in adherence to stringent quality standards, potentially impacting vehicle safety and performance.
normalised: new delhi, october twenty six – concerns are mounting over quality control procedures in india's auto ancillary sector, particularly among smaller vendors supplying components to major manufacturers like maruti suzuki and tata motors. recent audits have revealed inconsistencies in adherence to stringent quality standards, potentially impacting vehicle safety and performance.

unnormalised: The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi is reportedly collaborating with the Automotive Component Manufacturers Association of India (ACMA) to develop improved training modules and implement advanced quality control techniques. A recent ACMA report pointed towards a need for greater investment in testing infrastructure and skilled personnel.
normalised: the indian institute of technology (i i t) delhi is reportedly collaborating with the automotive component manufacturers association of india (a c m a) to develop improved training modules and implement advanced quality control techniques. a recent a c m a report pointed towards a need for greater investment in testing infrastructure and skilled personnel.

unnormalised: "Just like in '3 Idiots', where Rancho emphasized practical knowledge, our manufacturing needs a shift from rote learning to real-world application of quality principles," stated Mr. Rajesh Kumar, a senior quality control engineer at Bharat Forge. The sector is aiming to achieve 'zero defect, zero effect' manufacturing practices to meet growing domestic and export demands. The move is also partially motivated by the growing competition from Chinese and European suppliers.
normalised: "just like in 'three idiots', where rancho emphasized practical knowledge, our manufacturing needs a shift from rote learning to real-world application of quality principles," stated mister rajesh kumar, a senior quality control engineer at bharat forge. the sector is aiming to achieve 'zero defect, zero effect' manufacturing practices to meet growing domestic and export demands. the move is also partially motivated by the growing competition from chinese and european suppliers.

unnormalised: Rs. 200 crore investment is expected in this sector by next year.
normalised: rupees two hundred crore investment is expected in this sector by next year.

unnormalised: Vendors are required to have 5km radius to deliver the products.
normalised: vendors are required to have five kilometer radius to deliver the products.
